title: Assignment 4
text:
Difference between a weak and a strong entity set:

A strong entity set can be identified uniquely by its own attributes, such as an Employee with an Employee ID.
A weak entity set on the other hand, cannot be identified by its own attributes alone and depends on a strong entity (also known as the owner entity) for identification. An example could be a Dependent entity that relies on the Employee entity for its identification (e.g., an employee‚Äôs dependent might be identified by the Employee ID and Dependent‚Äôs name).

Using JSON YouTube: YouTube uses JSON to deliver video metadata, comments, and user interactions through its API. The JSON structure is hierarchical and includes nested fields for video IDs, thumbnails, and statistics such as views and likes. YouTube‚Äôs backend likely uses BigQuery and other Google Cloud services to store and manage data. The API fetches this data in JSON format, commonly consumed by frontend JavaScript frameworks.
Using XML W3Schools: W3Schools offers XML data examples, including a sample file that provides information on books. The XML structure uses descriptive tags such as , , and . The data can be accessed using XML parsers in JavaScript or server-side languages. Technologies like DOM and XSLT are used to query or transform the XML structure for web display.

title: Assignment 1
text:
Name and describe three applications you have used that employed a database system to store and access persistent data (e.g., airlines, online trade, banking, university system).



How it Uses Databases: Stores customer data, transactions, and account details.
Reasoning: Ensures secure, fast, and reliable access to banking information.





How it Uses Databases: Manages product listings, customer orders, and payments.
Reasoning: Uses a relational database to store structured data and provide recommendations.





How it Uses Databases: Stores student records, enrollments, and grades.
Reasoning: Ensures students and faculty have real-time access to course materials and academic records.





Propose three applications in domain projects (e.g., criminology, economics, brain science, etc.). Be sure to include: 1.Purpose 2.Functions 3.Simple interface design



Purpose: Measures and tracks social well-being indicators like mental health, employment, and community engagement.
Functions:

Collects survey responses on life satisfaction, stress levels, and social interactions.
Tracks changes in employment, education, and local crime rates.
Provides visual reports and insights for policymakers and community leaders.

Simple Interface Design: A dashboard displays key indicators like mental health scores, employment trends, and community engagement in charts and graphs. Users can fill out surveys to update data, and policymakers can generate reports with visual insights. The interface includes a homepage overview, survey page, and a report export option.





Purpose: Analyzes public sentiment on social issues by gathering data from social media and news sources.
Functions:

Collects and categorizes posts on topics like inequality, human rights, and policy changes.
Uses sentiment analysis to determine whether opinions are positive, negative, or neutral.
Generates reports on trending social issues over time.

Simple Interface Design: Users enter keywords to analyze public sentiment from news and social media, displayed through a word cloud, sentiment pie chart, and regional heatmap. A live feed shows relevant posts, and a report generation page allows data exports. The interface is search-focused with real-time insights.





Purpose: Tracks data on economic and social mobility to understand inequality trends in different regions.
Functions:

Stores data on income, education, and employment trends across communities.
Provides comparison charts on social mobility rates based on location, gender, and ethnicity.
Recommends policies and resources to improve access to opportunities.

Simple Interface Design: An interactive heat map and dashboard display income trends, education levels, and employment data by region. Users can compare multiple areas, view bar charts, and access policy recommendations. The interface supports searching, visual comparisons, and report downloads.




If data can be retrieved efficiently and effectively, why is data mining needed?
Data mining is essential because it allows us to extract meaningful insights from large datasets beyond just retrieving stored data. Below are key reasons why data mining is needed:




Databases can retrieve data efficiently, but they don‚Äôt automatically find patterns or trends.





Data mining helps predict future trends based on historical data.





Businesses use data mining to make data-driven decisions rather than relying on intuition.





Big data is too large and complex for traditional database queries alone. Data mining helps extract valuable insights from massive datasets.





Companies use data mining to gain a competitive edge by identifying market trends, customer preferences, and business risks.

title: Assignment 5
text:
Question 1: E-R Diagram as a Graph
An E-R (Entity-Relationship) diagram can be viewed as a graph, where entities are nodes and relationships are edges. Understanding its structure helps ensure database integrity and effective design.


a) The graph is disconnected
A disconnected graph means that some parts of the schema are isolated and do not connect to others. In terms of an enterprise schema, this implies that certain entities or relationships are not integrated with the rest of the database system.
Example: Imagine we have a Doctor entity and a Patient entity, but no relationship (like Treats) connecting them. These two entities are disconnected in the E-R diagram.
Implications: - Indicates missing relationships or a design flaw. - Can result in incomplete or difficult-to-query data. - Hurts the ability to enforce referential integrity.


b) The graph has a cycle
A cycle in an E-R diagram means that starting from one entity, you can follow a path of relationships and return to the same entity.
Example: Doctor ‚Üí Patient ‚Üí Test ‚Üí Doctor
This forms a loop (cycle) in the schema.
Implications: - Not inherently wrong ‚Äì cycles often represent real-world interconnectedness. - Can complicate queries, especially recursive ones. - May require careful normalization or handling to avoid data anomalies.


Question 3: Why Do We Have Weak Entity Sets?
While it‚Äôs possible to convert weak entity sets to strong ones by adding attributes, we still use weak entity sets in practice due to design clarity and efficiency.
Reasons We Use Weak Entity Sets:

A weak entity cannot be uniquely identified by its own attributes.
It depends on a related strong entity for uniqueness.

Why Not Always Use Strong Entities?

Making weak entities strong can require adding redundant or artificial keys, which is not always natural.
Weak entities simplify data modeling for real-world hierarchical relationships.
Helps maintain referential integrity and logical clarity in the schema.



Question 4


a: SQL Queries
Schema:
employee(ID, name, street, city)
works(ID, company_id, salary)
company(company_id, name, city)
manages(employee_id, manager_id)

Find ID and name of employees who live in the same city as the location of their company:

SELECT e.ID, e.name
FROM employee AS e, works AS w, company AS c
WHERE e.ID = w.ID AND w.company_id = c.company_id AND e.city = c.city;

Find ID and name of employees who live on the same street and in the same city as their manager:

SELECT e.ID, e.name
FROM employee AS e, manages AS m, employee AS mngr
WHERE e.ID = m.employee_id AND m.manager_id = mngr.ID
AND e.city = mngr.city AND e.street = mngr.street;

Find ID and name of employees who earn more than the average salary of all employees in their company:

SELECT e.ID, e.name
FROM employee AS e, works AS w
WHERE e.ID = w.ID AND w.salary > ( SELECT AVG(w2.salary)
FROM works AS w2
WHERE w2.company_id = w.company_id


b: What‚Äôs wrong with this SQL query?
SELECT name, title
FROM instructor NATURAL JOIN teaches NATURAL JOIN section NATURAL JOIN course
WHERE semester = ‚ÄòSpring‚Äô AND year = 2017;
Problem: This query uses NATURAL JOIN, which joins tables based on all columns with the same name. This can cause unintended matches, especially if tables have generic column names like ID or course_id.
Fix: Use explicit JOINs to clearly specify matching fields.
Corrected Query:
SELECT i.name, c.title
FROM instructor AS i
JOIN teaches AS t ON i.ID = t.ID
JOIN section AS s ON t.course_id = s.course_id
AND t.sec_id = s.sec_id
AND t.semester = s.semester
AND t.year = s.year JOIN course AS c ON s.course_id = c.course_id
WHERE s.semester = ‚ÄòSpring‚Äô AND s.year = 2017;

title: Part 4 ‚Äî Write a one page note on designing your website
text:
I created my website using Quarto and GitHub Pages to share my assignments, CV, and projects. The layout is simple and professional, with a top navigation bar for easy access to pages like Home, CV, and course assignments. A right-side ‚ÄúOn this page‚Äù panel helps visitors jump to sections quickly.
The site uses the Cosmo theme for clean styling and responsive design. Content is written in Markdown within .qmd files, making it easy to update and maintain. Images and files are stored in organized folders and linked using relative paths. I render the site locally and push updates to GitHub, where it‚Äôs automatically deployed.
My goal was to build a clear, functional, and easy-to-navigate portfolio that highlights my work while remaining simple to maintain and expand in the future.

title: Assignment 1
text:
Episode Overview
In this episode of Data Framed, hosts Adel Nehme and Richie Cotton welcome Karen Ng, Head of Product at HubSpot, to discuss the evolving landscape of team dynamics where humans and AI agents collaborate side by side. The conversation centers on practical strategies for integrating AI agents into workflows and optimizing team performance within this hybrid environment.

title: Assignment 1
text:
Main Theme
The central theme of the episode is the rise of human-plus-agent hybrid teams work environments in which AI systems share responsibilities with human workers. Karen Ng breaks down how organizations can effectively blend AI capabilities with human oversight, ensuring both productivity and ethical integrity.

title: Assignment 1
text:
Key Takeaways & Insights

Integration Strategy
Hybrid teams succeed when roles are clearly defined, and AI systems are introduced where they augment not replace human judgment.


Training & Evaluation
Establishing best practices for training AI agents includes designing them for continuous learning and setting evaluation criteria aligned with team goals.


Data Quality & Governance
A robust governance framework is crucial. AI agents must operate on accurate, reliable data while maintaining transparency and ethical standards.


Practical Use Cases
Industries like customer support, sales, and data processing have seen measurable benefits by integrating AI agents to handle recurring tasks freeing humans to focus on complex, strategic work.

title: Assignment 1
text:
Personal Reflection
This episode offers a forward-looking lens into how AI is reshaping team workflows. Karen Ng‚Äôs insights are grounded in real-world applications; her role at HubSpot lends credibility and depth to the discussion. I appreciated the balanced approach highlighting AI‚Äôs strengths while acknowledging the importance of human judgment, governance, and alignment with ethical standards.
I find the emphasis on governance particularly impactful. Too often, the conversation around AI overlooks the importance of data integrity and trust. This episode prompts listeners to think critically about implementing AI in a way that enhances not erodes team coherence and accountability.

Episode 319 of Data Framed delivers a timely and practical exploration of hybrid human-AI teamwork. It‚Äôs especially valuable for product managers, data team leaders, and anyone working at the intersection of AI and organizational design. Whether you‚Äôre exploring AI adoption or refining existing deployments, this episode offers a thoughtful roadmap for doing so responsibly and effectively.

title: Assignment 1
text:
The classic Anscombe‚Äôs quartet consists of four (x, y) datasets that share the same means, variances, correlations, and regression coefficients ‚Äî yet their scatterplots are visually very different. Below is my reproduction of the four datasets with their common least-squares line.




Anscombe‚Äôs quartet demonstrates that datasets with identical statistical summaries can tell very different stories when visualized. While all four share the same means, variances, correlations, and regression lines, their scatterplots reveal distinct problems: a roughly linear set, a curved relationship, a single extreme outlier, and a high-leverage point that determines the slope. Without visualization, these issues remain hidden and lead to incorrect conclusions. To address this, start with graphs (scatterplots plus a smooth), then check residuals, leverage, and Cook‚Äôs distance to test assumptions. When assumptions are violated, use robust regression, apply transformations, add nonlinear terms (e.g., a quadratic), or collect additional data to improve coverage across (x). This workflow ensures models reflect the true pattern rather than just matching aggregates.

title: Assignment 1
text:
3) Critique of a Published Chart
Source: The New York Times ‚Äî ‚ÄúCOVID-19 in the U.S.: Latest Map and Case Counts‚Äù
https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/us/covid-cases.html
Claim & audience. The interactive aims to show how COVID-19 cases evolve across U.S. geographies over time, serving a general audience tracking regional surges and declines.
What works. - The map + time-series pairing supports both geographic and temporal exploration. - Clean styling minimizes clutter; hover interactions surface detail on demand.
Issues:

Color encoding/contrast. Mid-range shades can be hard to distinguish on some displays, reducing perceptual separation between moderate and high values.

Axis/baseline clarity. In some views the y-axis does not start at zero; if truncation isn‚Äôt explicitly noted, fluctuations can appear exaggerated.

Context/annotation. Major events (e.g., vaccine rollout, variant waves) are not annotated on timelines, forcing readers to infer causes of spikes.

Legend proximity & cognitive load. Legends/scales can sit far from the immediate focus, increasing eye travel during comparison.

Accessibility. Palette choices may challenge color-vision deficiencies; thin strokes lower legibility on mobile.

Static use case. Exporting a static image removes tooltips/hover states, so meaning can be lost without added labels.

Improvements:

Adopt a colorblind-safe, high-contrast sequential palette (e.g., viridis) to better separate mid/high values.

Start y-axes at zero where feasible, or clearly mark breaks when truncation is necessary.

Add lightweight annotations at key dates (eligibility expansions, variant peaks) to anchor interpretation.

Move legend/scale closer to the plot area or directly label lines/peaks to reduce eye travel.

Use slightly thicker strokes and on-chart labels to retain meaning in static exports.

title: Assignment 3 ‚Äî Base R and ggplot2
text:
The six classic base R plots were recreated and displayed together in a 3√ó2 layout.
The figure below includes:
- A manually constructed scatterplot (‚ÄúBird 131‚Äù) with customized axes and dual labels.
- A histogram showing normally distributed data with a superimposed normal curve.
- A stacked bar chart for the VADeaths dataset with values labeled within each segment.
- Boxplots comparing ToothGrowth length by supplement type (OJ vs VC) and dose.
- A 3D perspective surface generated using the persp() function.
- A pie chart illustrating category shares using a gray tone color ramp.



I chose the ToothGrowth boxplot. It compares tooth length across Vitamin C doses (0.5, 1, 2 mg) and supplement type (OJ vs VC).
Each box shows the median (center line) and IQR (box height), with whiskers extending to data within 1.5√óIQR; any points beyond would be outliers.
From the figure, tooth length increases with dose, and at lower doses (0.5, 1 mg), OJ often shows higher medians than VC; by 2 mg, the two supplements are similar, indicating a diminishing difference at the highest dose.

title: Assignment 3 ‚Äî Base R and ggplot2
text:
2(a) Compare the regression models
All four datasets in Anscombe‚Äôs Quartet produce nearly identical regression statistics ‚Äî similar slopes, intercepts, and (R^2) values (approximately 0.67).
However, their visual patterns are completely different.
Set 1 represents a true linear relationship, Set 2 has a curved (nonlinear) trend, Set 3 contains a strong outlier that influences the regression, and Set 4 includes one high-leverage point that distorts the fitted line.
This demonstrates that numerical summaries alone can be misleading and highlights the importance of data visualization.

title: Assignment 3 ‚Äî Base R and ggplot2
text:
2(b) Compare different plotting styles
The first figure shows the default base plots for the four Anscombe datasets, while the second uses customized colors, symbols, and line types for clearer differentiation and readability.


Comparison paragraph:
The styled version communicates the differences between datasets much more effectively.
In Set 1, the linear trend is clear; in Set 2, curvature is visible; in Set 3, an outlier becomes obvious; and in Set 4, one leverage point dominates.
This comparison shows that thoughtful visual design ‚Äî through colors, line types, and shapes ‚Äî enhances interpretability and brings out patterns hidden in plain summaries.

title: Assignment 2 ‚Äî Base R Graphics (Murrell)
text:
Run Paul Murrell‚Äôs base R graphics programs (murrell01.R) line by line. Note the changes as low-level functions are added.



# Start plotting from basics
plot(pressure, pch = 16,
     xlab = "Temperature (Celsius)",
     ylab = "Pressure (mm Hg)",
     main = "Pressure vs Temperature")
text(150, 600, "Pressure (mm Hg)\nversus\nTemperature (Celsius)")







plot(pressure, pch = 5,
     xlab = "Temperature (Celsius)",
     ylab = "Pressure (mm Hg)",
     main = "Pressure vs Temperature (pch=5)")
text(150, 600, "Pressure (mm Hg)\nversus\nTemperature (Celsius)")









# Window + axes + layers
par(mfrow = c(1,1), las = 1, mar = c(4,4,2,4), cex = 0.9)

x  <- c(0.5, 2, 4, 8, 12, 16)
y1 <- c(1, 1.3, 1.9, 3.4, 3.9, 4.8)
y2 <- c(4, 0.8, 0.5, 0.45, 0.4, 0.3)

plot.new()
plot.window(xlim = range(as.numeric(x), na.rm = TRUE), ylim = c(0, 6))
lines(x, y1)
lines(x, y2)
points(x, y1, pch = 16, cex = 1.0)
points(x, y2, pch = 1, cex = 1.0)
axis(1, at = seq(0, 16, 4))
axis(2, at = seq(0, 6, 2))
axis(4, at = seq(0, 6, 2))
box(bty = "u")
mtext("Travel Time (s)", side = 1, line = 2)
mtext("Responses per Travel", side = 2, line = 2)
mtext("Responses per Second", side = 4, line = 2)
text(4, 5, "Bird 131")









# Histogram
set.seed(1)
Y <- rnorm(50)
Y[Y < -3.5 | Y > 3.5] <- NA
xg <- seq(-3.5, 3.5, 0.1)
hist(Y, breaks = seq(-3.5, 3.5), col = "gray80", freq = FALSE,
     main = "Normal sample", xlab = "Z", ylab = "Density")
lines(xg, dnorm(xg), lwd = 2)









# Barplot
par(mar = c(2, 3.1, 2, 2.1))
midpts <- barplot(VADeaths,
                  col = gray(0.1 + seq(1,9,2)/11),
                  names = rep("", 4),
                  ylab = "Death rate (per 1000)",
                  main = "VADeaths")
mtext(sub(" ", "\n", colnames(VADeaths)),
      at = midpts, side = 1, line = 0.5, cex = 0.7)







par(mar = c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))


# Boxplot
par(mar = c(3, 4.1, 2, 0))
boxplot(len ~ dose, data = ToothGrowth,
        boxwex = 0.25, at = 1:3 - 0.2,
        subset = supp == "VC", col = "white",
        xlab = "", ylab = "tooth length", ylim = c(0, 35),
        main = "ToothGrowth by dose & supplement")
mtext("Vitamin C dose (mg)", side = 1, line = 2.5, cex = 0.9)
boxplot(len ~ dose, data = ToothGrowth, add = TRUE,
        boxwex = 0.25, at = 1:3 + 0.2,
        subset = supp == "OJ")
legend(1.5, 9, c("Ascorbic acid", "Orange juice"),
       fill = c("white","gray"), bty = "n")







par(mar = c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))


# persp() demo surface
x <- seq(-10, 10, length = 30)
y <- x
f <- function(x,y) { r <- sqrt(x^2 + y^2); 10 * sin(r)/r }
z <- outer(x, y, f); z[is.na(z)] <- 1
par(mar = c(2, 2.5, 3, 2))
persp(x, y, z, theta = 30, phi = 30, expand = 0.5,
      ticktype = "detailed", xlab = "X", ylab = "Y", zlab = "Z",
      main = "persp(): demo surface")







par(mar = c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))


# Pie chart
par(mar = c(0, 2, 1, 2), xpd = FALSE, cex = 0.8)
pie.sales <- c(0.12, 0.30, 0.26, 0.16, 0.04, 0.12)
names(pie.sales) <- c("Blueberry","Cherry","Apple","Boston Cream","Other","Vanilla")
pie(pie.sales, col = gray(seq(0.3, 1.0, length = 6)),
    main = "Pie chart demo")

title: Assignment 2 ‚Äî Base R Graphics (Murrell)
text:
2.1 Base R Functions Used

par() ‚Äì Sets or queries graphical parameters such as margins, axis style, and layout.

lines() ‚Äì Adds connected line segments to an existing plot.

points() ‚Äì Adds individual points (symbols) to an existing plot.

axis() ‚Äì Draws tick marks and axis labels on plots.

box() ‚Äì Adds a box (border) around the current plotting region.

text() ‚Äì Writes text inside the plotting area at specified coordinates.

mtext() ‚Äì Adds text in the margins (outer areas) of the plot.

hist() ‚Äì Creates histograms for frequency distributions.

boxplot() ‚Äì Displays data distributions by quartiles.

legend() ‚Äì Adds legends identifying plotted elements.

persp() ‚Äì Produces 3-D perspective surface plots.

names() ‚Äì Retrieves or sets the names of variables in a data frame.

pie() ‚Äì Creates pie-chart visualizations.

title: Assignment 2 ‚Äî Base R Graphics (Murrell)
text:
2.2 Plots and Results

Make sure the file HPI_data.csv is in the same folder as this .qmd.


# Read and normalize column names from the HPI CSV. This maps your Excel-like
# headers to the short names used below, and ensures numeric types.
HPI_raw <- read.csv("HPI_data.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE, check.names = TRUE)

pick <- function(df, ...) {
  opts <- c(...)
  hit <- opts[opts %in% names(df)]
  if (!length(hit)) stop("Missing expected columns: ", paste(opts, collapse=" | "))
  df[[hit[1]]]
}

HPI <- data.frame(
  GDP_capita = suppressWarnings(as.numeric(pick(HPI_raw, "GDP_capita", "GDP.per.capita...."))),
  LifeExp    = suppressWarnings(as.numeric(pick(HPI_raw, "LifeExp", "Life.Expectancy..years."))),
  Wellbeing  = suppressWarnings(as.numeric(pick(HPI_raw, "Wellbeing", "Ladder.of.life..Wellbeing...0.10."))),
  Carbon     = suppressWarnings(as.numeric(pick(HPI_raw, "Carbon", "Carbon.Footprint..tCO2e."))),
  HPI        = suppressWarnings(as.numeric(pick(HPI_raw, "HPI"))),
  Population = suppressWarnings(as.numeric(pick(HPI_raw, "Population", "Population..thousands."))),
  Continent  = pick(HPI_raw, "Continent")
)


# Scatter with regression line ‚Äî small, solid points
scat <- subset(HPI, is.finite(LifeExp) & is.finite(Wellbeing))
par(las = 1, mar = c(4,4,2,1), cex = 0.9)
plot(scat$LifeExp, scat$Wellbeing, pch = 16, cex = 1.0, col = "steelblue",
     xlab = "Life Expectancy (years)", ylab = "Wellbeing (0‚Äì10)",
     main = "Life Expectancy vs Wellbeing (HPI)")
abline(lm(Wellbeing ~ LifeExp, data = scat), lwd = 2)
box()









# Custom axes & labels ‚Äî same point size as above
plot(scat$LifeExp, scat$Wellbeing, axes = FALSE, pch = 16, cex = 1.0, col = "steelblue",
     xlab = "", ylab = "", main = "Custom axes & labels (HPI)")
axis(1); axis(2); box()
text(x = mean(scat$LifeExp, na.rm = TRUE),
     y = max(scat$Wellbeing, na.rm = TRUE),
     labels = "Positive association", pos = 3)
mtext("Life Expectancy (Years)", side = 1, line = 3)
mtext("Wellbeing (0‚Äì10)",      side = 2, line = 3)









# Histogram + density
wb <- scat$Wellbeing[is.finite(scat$Wellbeing)]
hist(wb, breaks = 6, col = "gray80",
     main = "Distribution of Wellbeing (HPI)",
     xlab = "Wellbeing (0‚Äì10)", ylab = "Density")
if (length(unique(wb)) > 1) lines(density(wb), lwd = 2)









# Boxplot by continent
bp <- subset(HPI, is.finite(HPI) & !is.na(Continent))
boxplot(HPI ~ as.factor(Continent), data = bp, col = "white",
        ylab = "Happy Planet Index (HPI)", xlab = "Continent",
        main = "HPI by Continent")
mtext("Grouped distribution across regions", side = 3, line = 0.5, cex = 0.8)









# GDP vs Life Expectancy ‚Äî solid points
gdp <- subset(HPI, is.finite(GDP_capita) & is.finite(LifeExp))
plot(gdp$GDP_capita, gdp$LifeExp, pch = 16, cex = 1.0, col = "tomato",
     xlab = "GDP per Capita (USD)", ylab = "Life Expectancy (years)",
     main = "GDP vs Life Expectancy (HPI)")
legend("bottomright", legend = "Country points", pch = 16, col = "tomato", bty = "n")









# persp(): demo surface (with clear axes & ticks)
x <- seq(-10, 10, length = 30); y <- x
f <- function(x,y) {
  r <- sqrt(x^2 + y^2)
  out <- 10 * sin(r) / r
  out[!is.finite(out)] <- 10
  out
}
z <- outer(x, y, f)
par(mar = c(2, 2.5, 3, 2))
persp(x, y, z, theta = 30, phi = 30, expand = 0.5,
      ticktype = "detailed",
      xlab = "X", ylab = "Y", zlab = "Z",
      col = "lightblue", border = "gray30",
      main = "persp(): demo surface")









# OPTIONAL: Interpolated HPI surface using akima (only if enough data)
if (!requireNamespace("akima", quietly = TRUE)) {
  install.packages("akima")
}
if (requireNamespace("akima", quietly = TRUE)) {
  library(akima)
  df <- subset(HPI, is.finite(GDP_capita) & is.finite(Carbon) & is.finite(HPI))
  if (nrow(df) > 10 && length(unique(df$GDP_capita)) > 3 && length(unique(df$Carbon)) > 3) {
    interp_result <- with(df, akima::interp(x = GDP_capita, y = Carbon, z = HPI, duplicate = "mean"))
    par(mar = c(2, 2.5, 3, 2))
    persp(interp_result$x, interp_result$y, interp_result$z,
          theta = 30, phi = 30, expand = 0.5,
          ticktype = "detailed",
          xlab = "GDP per Capita", ylab = "Carbon (tCO2e/capita)", zlab = "HPI",
          col = "lightblue", border = "gray30",
          main = "HPI Surface: GDP vs Carbon (interpolated)")
  } else {
    message("Not enough distinct points for interpolation; skipping HPI surface.")
  }
}

title: Prepare for Class 2
text:
‚ÄúTeaching to See‚Äù is a 37-minute primer on visual literacy and studio discipline. Inge Druckrey, drawing on the Basel School tradition, shows how designers learn to see‚Äînot merely to look at objects, but to perceive relationships: proportion, rhythm, weight, contrast, spacing, and alignment. The film‚Äôs early exercises are intentionally humble‚Äîparallel lines, curves, letterforms, cropping‚Äîbecause they train attention. Druckrey‚Äôs core idea is that the eye must be calibrated through deliberate practice so it can make fine distinctions and judge quality without relying on rules of thumb. That calibration then guides the hand, which becomes a precise instrument rather than a source of accidental marks.
Two themes recur. Sensitivity to contrast (thin/thick, light/dark, dense/open): students push differences until they can control them, which later allows subtlety. Structure and continuity: how a curve carries energy across space; how a line‚Äôs direction implies movement; how negative space shapes the figure as much as strokes do. By iterating studies and pinning work to the wall, students learn comparative judgment‚Äîwhy one arrangement breathes while another feels cramped; why a tiny shift in alignment or spacing can turn awkwardness into clarity. Druckrey frames this as ethics as much as technique: careful seeing is respect for the viewer‚Äôs time.
The film also connects craft to technology. Good digital typography, interface spacing, and iconography all sit on the same foundations as pen-and-ink calligraphy: consistent stroke logic, optical corrections for perception, and hierarchy established through size, weight, and white space. The cameo references to Steve Jobs underline this continuity‚Äîhumanist calligraphy informed the Macintosh‚Äôs attention to typography, kerning, and proportionally spaced fonts‚Äîreminding us that useful software inherits from analog craft. Ultimately, ‚ÄúTeaching to See‚Äù argues that design education is less about memorizing rules and more about training judgment. The reward is work that is quiet, exact, and humane‚Äîdesign that ‚Äúdisappears‚Äù because its structure is so well seen.

title: Prepare for Class 2
text:
‚ÄúTeaching to See‚Äù is a 37-minute primer on visual literacy and studio discipline. Inge Druckrey, drawing on the Basel School tradition, shows how designers learn to see‚Äînot merely to look at objects, but to perceive relationships: proportion, rhythm, weight, contrast, spacing, and alignment. The film‚Äôs early exercises are intentionally humble‚Äîparallel lines, curves, letterforms, cropping‚Äîbecause they train attention. Druckrey‚Äôs core idea is that the eye must be calibrated through deliberate practice so it can make fine distinctions and judge quality without relying on rules of thumb. That calibration then guides the hand, which becomes a precise instrument rather than a source of accidental marks.
Two themes recur. Sensitivity to contrast (thin/thick, light/dark, dense/open): students push differences until they can control them, which later allows subtlety. Structure and continuity: how a curve carries energy across space; how a line‚Äôs direction implies movement; how negative space shapes the figure as much as strokes do. By iterating studies and pinning work to the wall, students learn comparative judgment‚Äîwhy one arrangement breathes while another feels cramped; why a tiny shift in alignment or spacing can turn awkwardness into clarity. Druckrey frames this as ethics as much as technique: careful seeing is respect for the viewer‚Äôs time.
The film also connects craft to technology. Good digital typography, interface spacing, and iconography all sit on the same foundations as pen-and-ink calligraphy: consistent stroke logic, optical corrections for perception, and hierarchy established through size, weight, and white space. The cameo references to Steve Jobs underline this continuity‚Äîhumanist calligraphy informed the Macintosh‚Äôs attention to typography, kerning, and proportionally spaced fonts‚Äîreminding us that useful software inherits from analog craft. Ultimately, ‚ÄúTeaching to See‚Äù argues that design education is less about memorizing rules and more about training judgment. The reward is work that is quiet, exact, and humane‚Äîdesign that ‚Äúdisappears‚Äù because its structure is so well seen.

title: Prepare for Class 2
text:
Guided Questions

1) Learn thin/thick and curve/linearity from Druckrey
Druckrey teaches contrast and line quality through repetitive, controlled studies. Using broad- and fine-nib tools, students draw series of parallel strokes to feel how pressure and angle create thin‚Äìthick modulation. Curve drills‚Äîlong, continuous S-curves and circles‚Äîbuild continuity and pacing, while straight-line studies enforce steadiness and alignment. By comparing dozens of iterations on the wall, students learn to judge consistency of stroke, even spacing, clean joins at corners, and transitions where a curve straightens into a line. The aim is sensitivity: to control contrast deliberately rather than by accident.


2) How did Holmes describe and contrast the eye and the hand in writing?
Nigel Holmes‚Äôs point (as echoed in the film‚Äôs commentary) is that the eye is fast, comparative, and judgment-driven, while the hand is slow, mechanical, and trainable. The eye anticipates form‚Äîspacing, direction, and weight‚Äîand immediately perceives unevenness; the hand must practice until it can execute what the eye intends. Good drawing and writing align the two: the seeing leads, the hand follows. When they are out of sync you get wobbly lines, inconsistent spacing, and tired letterforms; when aligned, the marks feel alive and effortless.


3) Why is calligraphy important to Steve Jobs and the design of Mac computers?
Jobs famously audited a calligraphy course at Reed College. From it he absorbed the grammar of letterforms‚Äîstroke contrast, serif logic, rhythm, kerning, and optical spacing. Those lessons shaped the original Macintosh: multiple typefaces, proportionally spaced fonts, and attention to typographic detail were prioritized in software and hardware. The humanist values of calligraphy‚Äîclarity, proportion, and respect for the reader‚Äîbecame product principles.


4) Differentiate geometric accuracy and optical accuracy
Geometric accuracy is what a ruler or coordinates say is equal; optical accuracy is what looks equal. Because of human perception, purely geometric equality often appears wrong. Designers make ‚Äúoptical corrections‚Äù: circles and curved letters overshoot the baseline and cap height; counters are opened to avoid clogging; horizontal and vertical spacing is adjusted so masses feel even; centered objects are nudged to compensate for visual weight. In training the eye, Druckrey stresses judging with perception first and letting geometry serve that judgment.

title: Prepare for Class 3
text:
Geoff McGhee‚Äôs documentary Journalism in the Age of Data explores how visualization became central to modern storytelling. Through interviews with data journalists at The New York Times, The Guardian, and Gapminder, the film reveals a shift: journalists no longer just write stories‚Äîthey design arguments that readers can explore visually. The craft moves beyond illustration; graphics are the narrative.
Academic visualization, by contrast, tends to emphasize analytical precision, statistical rigor, and reproducibility. In scholarly work, clarity and neutrality are paramount; visuals must represent data truthfully, often at the expense of aesthetic engagement. Journalistic visualization, on the other hand, embraces emotion and immediacy. It borrows from design to guide attention‚Äîusing color, motion, and annotation to shape interpretation. McGhee frames this as a collaboration between story and structure: the journalist curates context so that readers can navigate complex issues like climate change or budgets intuitively.
Another key distinction lies in audience. Academic visualizations address expert readers who can decode abstract charts; journalistic ones target general publics who need the visualization to invite curiosity rather than prove a hypothesis. Yet both domains share a mission: to make invisible systems visible. As McGhee notes, good visualization demands technical literacy and moral restraint‚Äîknowing what to emphasize and what to omit.
Ultimately, Journalism in the Age of Data bridges the gap between scientific visualization and narrative design. It argues that the journalist‚Äôs role has expanded from storyteller to explainer, translator, and data designer. When done well, this synthesis turns raw information into understanding‚Äîan act both analytic and artistic.

title: Prepare for Class 4
text:
Edward Tufte‚Äôs lecture The Future of Data Analysis extends his lifelong campaign for clarity and integrity in how information is displayed. He opens with a simple but radical idea: seeing well is thinking well. In a world overflowing with dashboards, metrics, and automated analytics, Tufte argues that the next frontier of data analysis is not technological‚Äîit is philosophical. What matters most is cultivating the human capacity to notice patterns, relationships, and meaning hidden within complexity. Tools can calculate, but only the human mind can interpret.
Throughout the talk, Tufte revisits his central design principles‚Äîtruthfulness, precision, and beauty‚Äîand re-frames them for an era dominated by algorithms. He traces a line from Galileo‚Äôs telescopic sketches to today‚Äôs interactive data dashboards, reminding the audience that visualization has always been a cognitive technology: a way to extend perception and reasoning. When we visualize data, we are literally ‚Äúmaking thought visible.‚Äù Yet he warns that as graphics become more automated, the analyst‚Äôs curiosity and skepticism can erode. ‚ÄúNever let the software think for you,‚Äù he says, stressing that each chart must emerge from a clear analytical question rather than a template.
A major theme is integration‚Äîof quantitative accuracy with qualitative understanding. Tufte envisions the analyst of the future as both scientist and artist, someone who can write statistical code and also judge visual proportion, hierarchy, and rhythm. This combination of reasoning and design, he suggests, produces visualizations that work‚Äîthey inform without distorting and persuade without manipulating. He calls for ‚Äúhigh data density with low noise,‚Äù meaning that every pixel should carry meaning and every visual choice should serve evidence, not decoration.
The talk also critiques the overuse of dashboards and ‚Äúchartjunk.‚Äù When organizations rely on flashy but shallow summaries, they risk mistaking performance metrics for knowledge. Tufte argues that genuine understanding requires context: side-by-side comparisons, annotated evidence, and time-series continuity. His principle of small multiples‚Äîrepeated, comparable views‚Äîremains one of the most powerful ways to show change without exaggeration. He contrasts this disciplined approach with sensational graphs that truncate axes or hide uncertainty, calling such distortions ethical failures, not mere design flaws.
Another striking idea is the role of narrative in analysis. Tufte insists that visualization should not replace verbal explanation but enhance it. Numbers and stories must coexist: data show what happened, while narrative clarifies why it matters. The most effective visualizations invite the viewer to reason, not just react. They slow perception down enough for reflection‚Äîa quality increasingly rare in the fast-scroll world of media and business intelligence tools.
By the end, Tufte situates the ‚Äúfuture‚Äù of data analysis in a moral framework. The abundance of data amplifies both our power and our responsibility. Analysts and designers are now interpreters of reality; their choices can clarify truth or conceal it. He challenges his audience to treat every visualization as an ethical document‚Äîsomething that must earn trust through accuracy, transparency, and aesthetic restraint.
Ultimately, Tufte‚Äôs message is timeless: technology may evolve, but the principles of clear thinking do not. The real progress in data analysis will come not from more dashboards, but from deeper attention. The analyst of the future is not a technician running models, but a human observer capable of transforming raw information into understanding.


‚ÄúThe future of data analysis is not a machine. It‚Äôs a human being with better eyesight.‚Äù ‚Äî Edward Tufte

title: Prepare for Class 5
text:
Big data has reshaped how we understand social behavior, public health, and markets‚Äîbut with its scale comes illusion. The Parable of Google Flu, published in Nature, remains a cautionary tale. In 2008, Google‚Äôs algorithm predicted flu outbreaks by analyzing search queries, claiming to forecast epidemics faster than the CDC. For a brief period, the results looked revolutionary‚Äîuntil they stopped working. The algorithm overestimated flu cases by more than 140%, revealing that the apparent success of ‚Äúbig data‚Äù can mask deeper analytical flaws.
The first pitfall is data without theory. Massive datasets tempt analysts to treat correlation as causation. Without grounding in domain knowledge, we misinterpret noise as signal. In the Google Flu case, rising media attention and public anxiety‚Äîrather than infection rates‚Äîdrove search trends. This created a self-reinforcing feedback loop that the model mistook for real-world growth. Tufte‚Äôs warning about ‚Äúseeing without thinking‚Äù echoes here: visualization and data alike require interpretation, not just computation.
Another pitfall is algorithmic opacity. Big data often relies on proprietary, ever-changing systems. When inputs, models, or weighting methods are unknown, replication becomes impossible. This erodes scientific transparency and accountability‚Äîtwo pillars of credible data analysis. Furthermore, as datasets grow, bias does not disappear; it scales. If underlying data are incomplete, unrepresentative, or contextually skewed, bigger datasets simply reproduce error with greater confidence.
Closely related is the danger of overfitting and overparameterization. In large models, especially machine learning systems, it‚Äôs easy to fit data so perfectly that the model memorizes patterns rather than generalizes them. This creates high accuracy in training but failure in prediction. Overfitting is a form of overconfidence disguised as precision‚Äîit reflects modeling power used without restraint. The solution, as both Hadley Wickham and Andrew Gelman emphasize, lies in simplicity, cross-validation, and clarity: build models that explain rather than impress.
Ethically, the pitfalls of big data remind us that quantity does not equal quality. A million observations cannot compensate for poor measurement, biased sampling, or conceptual confusion. The role of the analyst is to filter wisely, visualize responsibly, and remain skeptical of ‚Äútoo-good-to-be-true‚Äù correlations. In the end, meaningful data analysis depends not on how much data we have, but on how thoughtfully we use it.

title: Prepare for Class 5
section: Hadley Wickham: Data Visualization and Data Science (EMBL) ‚Äî Summary and Commentary
text:
Hadley Wickham: Data Visualization and Data Science (EMBL) ‚Äî Summary and Commentary
In his EMBL talk, Hadley Wickham explains that data visualization is the bridge between data and understanding. He introduces the ‚Äúgrammar of graphics‚Äù ‚Äî a structured way to describe visualizations as combinations of data, aesthetic mappings, and geometries. This framework, implemented in his ggplot2 package, allows analysts to move from ad-hoc plotting to reproducible, composable graphics. Every visual element in a chart‚Äîpoints, lines, bars, colors, or facets‚Äîcorresponds to a decision in the grammar, making visual design transparent and logical.
Wickham also connects visualization to the broader workflow of data science: importing, tidying, transforming, visualizing, and modeling. He emphasizes that visualization is not the end of analysis but the middle of thinking‚Äîa feedback loop that helps analysts notice patterns, spot errors, and refine questions. The best insights often emerge while visualizing, not after modeling.
Another key contribution is his advocacy for tidy data principles, where each variable forms a column, each observation a row, and each dataset a table. This structure allows visualization tools and analytical packages to interoperate seamlessly. Combined with ggplot2, dplyr, and tidyr, the tidyverse creates an ecosystem where clarity, readability, and reproducibility come first.
Wickham‚Äôs main message parallels Tufte‚Äôs: clarity is ethics in data visualization. The goal is not to impress audiences with complexity but to reveal truth with simplicity. In practice, this means designing graphics that emphasize structure over style, accuracy over decoration, and transparency over spectacle. His work has transformed visualization from a craft of intuition into a system of reasoning‚Äîa grammar that turns data into readable, trustworthy stories.


‚ÄúThe purpose of visualization is not to show data; it‚Äôs to make people think about data.‚Äù ‚Äî Hadley Wickham

In large models, especially machine learning systems, it‚Äôs easy to fit data so perfectly that the model memorizes patterns rather than generalizes them. This creates high accuracy in training but failure in prediction. Overfitting is a form of overconfidence disguised as precision‚Äîit reflects modeling power used without restraint. The solution, as both Hadley Wickham and Andrew Gelman emphasize, lies in simplicity, cross-validation, and clarity: build models that explain rather than impress.
Ethically, the pitfalls of big data remind us that quantity does not equal quality. A million observations cannot compensate for poor measurement, biased sampling, or conceptual confusion. The role of the analyst is to filter wisely, visualize responsibly, and remain skeptical of ‚Äútoo-good-to-be-true‚Äù correlations. In the end, meaningful data analysis depends not on how much data we have, but on how thoughtfully we use it.

title: Prepare for Class 5
section: Hadley Wickham: Data Visualization and Data Science (EMBL) ‚Äî Summary and Commentary
text:
Hadley Wickham: Data Visualization and Data Science (EMBL) ‚Äî Summary and Commentary
In his EMBL talk, Hadley Wickham explains that data visualization is the bridge between data and understanding. He introduces the ‚Äúgrammar of graphics‚Äù ‚Äî a structured way to describe visualizations as combinations of data, aesthetic mappings, and geometries. This framework, implemented in his ggplot2 package, allows analysts to move from ad-hoc plotting to reproducible, composable graphics. Every visual element in a chart‚Äîpoints, lines, bars, colors, or facets‚Äîcorresponds to a decision in the grammar, making visual design transparent and logical.
Wickham also connects visualization to the broader workflow of data science: importing, tidying, transforming, visualizing, and modeling. He emphasizes that visualization is not the end of analysis but the middle of thinking‚Äîa feedback loop that helps analysts notice patterns, spot errors, and refine questions. The best insights often emerge while visualizing, not after modeling.
Another key contribution is his advocacy for tidy data principles, where each variable forms a column, each observation a row, and each dataset a table. This structure allows visualization tools and analytical packages to interoperate seamlessly. Combined with ggplot2, dplyr, and tidyr, the tidyverse creates an ecosystem where clarity, readability, and reproducibility come first.
Wickham‚Äôs main message parallels Tufte‚Äôs: clarity is ethics in data visualization. The goal is not to impress audiences with complexity but to reveal truth with simplicity. In practice, this means designing graphics that emphasize structure over style, accuracy over decoration, and transparency over spectacle. His work has transformed visualization from a craft of intuition into a system of reasoning‚Äîa grammar that turns data into readable, trustworthy stories.


‚ÄúThe purpose of visualization is not to show data; it‚Äôs to make people think about data.‚Äù ‚Äî Hadley Wickham

title: Prepare for Class 4
text:
Edward Tufte‚Äôs lecture The Future of Data Analysis extends his lifelong campaign for clarity and integrity in how information is displayed. He opens with a simple but radical idea: seeing well is thinking well. In a world overflowing with dashboards, metrics, and automated analytics, Tufte argues that the next frontier of data analysis is not technological‚Äîit is philosophical. What matters most is cultivating the human capacity to notice patterns, relationships, and meaning hidden within complexity. Tools can calculate, but only the human mind can interpret.
Throughout the talk, Tufte revisits his central design principles‚Äîtruthfulness, precision, and beauty‚Äîand re-frames them for an era dominated by algorithms. He traces a line from Galileo‚Äôs telescopic sketches to today‚Äôs interactive data dashboards, reminding the audience that visualization has always been a cognitive technology: a way to extend perception and reasoning. When we visualize data, we are literally ‚Äúmaking thought visible.‚Äù Yet he warns that as graphics become more automated, the analyst‚Äôs curiosity and skepticism can erode. ‚ÄúNever let the software think for you,‚Äù he says, stressing that each chart must emerge from a clear analytical question rather than a template.
A major theme is integration‚Äîof quantitative accuracy with qualitative understanding. Tufte envisions the analyst of the future as both scientist and artist, someone who can write statistical code and also judge visual proportion, hierarchy, and rhythm. This combination of reasoning and design, he suggests, produces visualizations that work‚Äîthey inform without distorting and persuade without manipulating. He calls for ‚Äúhigh data density with low noise,‚Äù meaning that every pixel should carry meaning and every visual choice should serve evidence, not decoration.
The talk also critiques the overuse of dashboards and ‚Äúchartjunk.‚Äù When organizations rely on flashy but shallow summaries, they risk mistaking performance metrics for knowledge. Tufte argues that genuine understanding requires context: side-by-side comparisons, annotated evidence, and time-series continuity. His principle of small multiples‚Äîrepeated, comparable views‚Äîremains one of the most powerful ways to show change without exaggeration. He contrasts this disciplined approach with sensational graphs that truncate axes or hide uncertainty, calling such distortions ethical failures, not mere design flaws.
Another striking idea is the role of narrative in analysis. Tufte insists that visualization should not replace verbal explanation but enhance it. Numbers and stories must coexist: data show what happened, while narrative clarifies why it matters. The most effective visualizations invite the viewer to reason, not just react. They slow perception down enough for reflection‚Äîa quality increasingly rare in the fast-scroll world of media and business intelligence tools.
By the end, Tufte situates the ‚Äúfuture‚Äù of data analysis in a moral framework. The abundance of data amplifies both our power and our responsibility. Analysts and designers are now interpreters of reality; their choices can clarify truth or conceal it. He challenges his audience to treat every visualization as an ethical document‚Äîsomething that must earn trust through accuracy, transparency, and aesthetic restraint.
Ultimately, Tufte‚Äôs message is timeless: technology may evolve, but the principles of clear thinking do not. The real progress in data analysis will come not from more dashboards, but from deeper attention. The analyst of the future is not a technician running models, but a human observer capable of transforming raw information into understanding.


‚ÄúThe future of data analysis is not a machine. It‚Äôs a human being with better eyesight.‚Äù ‚Äî Edward Tufte

section: 2. Scrape Foreign Exchange Reserves Table (Original Task)
text:
2. Scrape Foreign Exchange Reserves Table (Original Task)

url_fx <- "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_foreign-exchange_reserves"

fx_page <- read_html(url_fx)

# Extract all tables
fx_tables <- html_table(html_nodes(fx_page, "table"), fill = TRUE)

# Use the first table with country-wise reserves
fx_df <- fx_tables[[1]]

# Fix duplicated column names
names(fx_df) <- make.names(names(fx_df), unique = TRUE)

# Rename and clean
fx_clean <- fx_df %>%
  rename(
    Country = 1,
    Reserves_USD_Billion = 2,
    Date = 3,
    Source = 4
  ) %>%
  filter(!is.na(Reserves_USD_Billion), Country != "") %>%
  mutate(
    Reserves_USD_Billion = as.numeric(gsub(",", "", Reserves_USD_Billion)),
    Date = str_trim(Date)
  )

section: 5. Suggest a Data Plan for Research
text:
5. Suggest a Data Plan for Research

To study global financial preparedness and development levels, I propose merging Wikipedia data on foreign reserves and GDP by country. This will allow researchers to calculate the ratio of foreign reserves to GDP, a useful indicator for macroeconomic stability and risk exposure. Future work may include scraping literacy rate, inflation, or debt data to analyze patterns across regions using R visualizations, regressions, and mapping tools.

Both cleaned datasets are exported and linked above for download.

title: Assignment 5: Government Data API
text:
This assignment demonstrates how to access and download government data using the GovInfo API, focusing on the ten most recent documents from the Foreign Relations Committee.
The script automates data retrieval, cleaning, and export into a CSV file.

title: Assignment 5: Government Data API
text:
This assignment demonstrates how to access and download government data using the GovInfo API, focusing on the ten most recent documents from the Foreign Relations Committee.
The script automates data retrieval, cleaning, and export into a CSV file.

title: Assignment 5: Government Data API
text:
2. R Script: Govt Data Retrieval

# -------------------------------
# Load Required Libraries
# -------------------------------
library(httr)
library(jsonlite)
library(dplyr)

# -------------------------------
# Define API URL and Parameters
# -------------------------------
base_url <- "https://api.govinfo.gov/search"
api_key <- "DEMO_KEY"  # Replace with your actual API key from https://api.govinfo.gov/docs/api/key/

params <- list(
  query = "Foreign Relations Committee",
  pageSize = 10,
  sortBy = "date",
  sortOrder = "desc",
  api_key = api_key
)

# -------------------------------
# API Request
# -------------------------------
response <- GET(base_url, query = params)

if (status_code(response) == 200) {
  data <- content(response, as = "text", encoding = "UTF-8")
  json_data <- fromJSON(data, flatten = TRUE)
  
  # Extract relevant fields
  docs <- json_data$results %>%
    select(title, collectionCode, dateIssued, govInfoLink = link)
  
  # Save to CSV
  write.csv(docs, "ForeignRelations_10Docs.csv", row.names = FALSE)
  
  print("‚úÖ Data successfully saved as ForeignRelations_10Docs.csv")
  head(docs)
  
} else {
  print(paste("‚ùå API request failed with status:", status_code(response)))
}

title: Assignment 5: Government Data API
text:
4. Reflection Report

4.1 Difficulties Encountered

API Key Access ‚Äî The GovInfo API requires a registered key; using the demo key can restrict access or limit the number of requests.

Complex JSON Structure ‚Äî Extracting relevant elements like title, date, and links required flattening nested lists.

Query Sensitivity ‚Äî Generic searches for ‚ÄúForeign Relations Committee‚Äù sometimes returned unrelated documents without filters.

Pagination & Sorting ‚Äî Ensuring the newest records appeared first required sortBy = "date" and sortOrder = "desc".




4.2 How Usable Was the Scraped Data?
The resulting dataset was structured and well-formatted, containing document metadata (titles, collection codes, dates, and links).
While the data is clean and suitable for statistical analysis or visualization, the document content itself (e.g., full hearing transcripts) is not included ‚Äî only the metadata and URLs.



4.3 How to Improve

Text Extraction: Use pdftools to download and extract text from linked documents for deeper content analysis.

Automated Scheduling: Implement cronR or taskscheduleR to update datasets regularly.

Advanced Filtering: Include additional parameters like collectionCode = 'CHRG' to narrow to congressional hearings.

Visualization: Add summary charts (e.g., document counts by year or committee).

title: Assignment 5: Government Data API
text:
5. Conclusion
This assignment highlights the importance of API-based government data access for reproducible research.
Through this workflow, analysts can directly retrieve structured data, analyze policy documents, and maintain transparency and replicability in social research.

title: Assignment 4 ‚Äî Data Visualization Hackathon
text:
Overview
This page presents four charts produced in R for the Assignment 4 hackathon. The structure mirrors the reference example, with each chart in its own section containing:

A short design rationale (goal, audience, design choices),
Reproducible R code (using ggplot2), and
The rendered figure.


Note on datasets: To ensure this renders anywhere without external files, this page uses built-in R datasets (mpg, economics) that ship with ggplot2. You can swap in your own data later while keeping the same structure.




Reusable Setup



Chart 1 ‚Äî Scatter with trend & annotation

p1 <- ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.8, size = 2) +
  geom_smooth(method = "loess", se = TRUE) +
  labs(
    title = "Bigger Engines, Lower MPG",
    subtitle = "Highway MPGs generally decrease as engine displacement increases",
    x = "Engine Displacement (liters)",
    y = "Highway MPG",
    caption = "Source: ggplot2::mpg"
  ) +
  viz_theme()

p1

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'












Chart 2 ‚Äî Ranked bars with labels

rank_dat <- mpg %>%
  group_by(manufacturer) %>%
  summarise(avg_cty = mean(cty, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  arrange(desc(avg_cty)) %>%
  slice_head(n = 12) %>%
  mutate(manufacturer = reorder(manufacturer, avg_cty))

p2 <- ggplot(rank_dat, aes(x = manufacturer, y = avg_cty)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip() +
  geom_text(aes(label = round(avg_cty, 1)), hjust = -0.05, size = 3.2) +
  expand_limits(y = max(rank_dat$avg_cty) * 1.12) +
  labs(
    title = "Who‚Äôs Most Efficient in the City?",
    subtitle = "Average city MPG by manufacturer (top 12)",
    x = NULL, y = "Avg City MPG",
    caption = "Source: ggplot2::mpg"
  ) +
  viz_theme()

p2











Chart 3 ‚Äî Time series with recession bands

recessions <- data.frame(
  start = as.Date(c("1973-11-01", "1980-01-01", "1981-07-01", "1990-07-01", "2001-03-01", "2007-12-01")),
  end   = as.Date(c("1975-03-01", "1980-07-01", "1982-11-01", "1991-03-01", "2001-11-01", "2009-06-01"))
)

p3 <- ggplot(economics, aes(x = date, y = unemploy)) +
  geom_rect(data = recessions, inherit.aes = FALSE,
            aes(xmin = start, xmax = end, ymin = -Inf, ymax = Inf),
            alpha = 0.12) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 0.8) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = label_number(scale_cut = cut_si(""))) +
  labs(
    title = "Unemployment Rises in Downturns",
    subtitle = "Shaded bands show select recession periods",
    x = NULL, y = "Unemployed persons",
    caption = "Source: ggplot2::economics; recessions illustrative"
  ) +
  viz_theme()

p3











Chart 4 ‚Äî Distribution (box/violin)

mpg2 <- mpg %>% mutate(cyl_f = factor(cyl))

p4 <- ggplot(mpg2, aes(x = drv, y = hwy)) +
  geom_violin(trim = TRUE, alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_boxplot(width = 0.12, outlier.alpha = 0.25) +
  facet_wrap(~ cyl_f, nrow = 2) +
  labs(
    title = "Efficiency Differs by Drivetrain & Cylinders",
    subtitle = "Distributions of highway MPG across drive types, split by cylinder count",
    x = "Drivetrain (f = FWD, r = RWD, 4 = 4WD)",
    y = "Highway MPG",
    caption = "Source: ggplot2::mpg"
  ) +
  viz_theme()

p4
